title: 2025 Sea Otter Classic: Haute Bicycle Co XO-1 Tribute by Cane Creek – John Watson
content:
Our 2025 Sea Otter Classic coverage will continue to highlight the Beautiful Bicycles we come across in individual galleries. Let’s check out this rad Haute Bicycle Co XO-1 Tribute by Cane Creek below! Read on as John breaks this one down…

I’ve seen quite a few Bridgestone XO-1 homage bikes, but the Haute Bicycle Co XO-1 tribute by Cane Creek brings something entirely different to the table. While Grant Petersen, the original XO-1 designer, might not spec 1x drive trains, disc brakes, and suspension forks, on his Rivendell models, it’s hard to argue that the XO-1’s legacy isn’t thriving in this homage. Richmond, Virginia-based Haute Bikes knocked it out of the park. 804 is the city’s area code and the Bridgestone typeface flip is uncanny.

Bridgestone’s MB-1 came out in 1987, five years before the XO-1, and donned “dirt drops.” Years of “cold-setting” aluminum Cinelli Criterium bars set the hook in the early mountain bike companies. This trend took off in the mainstream production market only after the pioneers at WTB – Charlie Cunningham, Steve Potts, and Ibis’ Scot Nicol – developed MTB drop bars with Specialized. While the MB-1 has been regarded as the first production bike to include dirt drops, WTB’s founders had been doing it for many years prior.

The XO-1, however, was the first bike to be specced with mustache bars, which took this trend and flattened it… literally.

As shown above, Bridgestone only made 1000 units of the Pumpkin Orange XO-1 with mustache bars. These bars were imagined as completely flattened dirt drops, offering a multitude of hand positions, yet still relying on drop bar brake levers and barcon shifters. In flattening the bars, Petersen relied on higher stack than the NORBA racing bikes of the era, omitting the need for a Scot Nicol-designed Gooseneck stem. These were casual-pace country bikes, designed for gravel road riding.

It’s easy to see that Petersen has always been a bike design genius. The XO-1 was perfection.

Rather than going with a modern version of the XO-1’s mustache bars, Cane Creek product marketing manager Will Hart specced the Haut homage with Ritchey drop bars. However, Will stayed true to the original bike and kept the iconic “pumpkin orange” paint. A silver GXC Cane Creek stem, custom-painted Invert CS fork, paired with eeWings and a GRX spider, with a beautiful silver eeSilk seatpost,

Classic bikes like the XO-1 and the mind behind them continue to inform our modern bikes today. Homages like this are a direct link between old and new.. What is perhaps the most interesting about a true modern interpretation like this is how much work and thoughtfulness goes into the interpretation, and even modern compromises like disc brakes, suspension, and drop bars still feel true to form.

If you want to see behind the scenes of this project, roll on over to Cane Creek’s blog for more! And check out what’s going on in the 804 at Haute Bicycle Co.
